passages.text: 2025 results above on revenue/margin beats. US\(5bn share repurchase program announced
TCOM12m Price Target: $87.00Price: $65.29Upside: 33.3%9961.HK12m Price Target: HK$679.00Price: HK$552.00Upside: 23.0%
Asia Leisure Insights into Casinos, Airlines, Duty Free, Hainan, Hotels, OTA & the Rise of Leisure

Given the healthy travel momentum in 2Q25 esp. during the May Labor Day holidays, TCOM delivered another solid set of results as flagged in our preview note (Aug 7), beating its rather conservative revenue and margin guidance. Specifically, group revenue grew steadily \(+16\%\) yoy (vs. \(+16\%\) yoy in 1Q25 and toward the high- end of its \(12 - 17\%\) yoy guidance) again driven by strong growth from its international Trip.com platform (+55% yoy inline with 1Q25) and resilient performance from both domestic (+11% vs. \(+10\%\) yoy in 1Q25) and outbound travel (+15% vs. \(+19\%\) yoy in 1Q25) - both outperforming industry growth marginally in volume terms partly offset by price

decline. EBIT came in \(9\%\) above consensus estimates (+4% above GSE) and rose \(+10\%\) yoy to Rmb4.7bn, implying - 1.7pts yoy margin contraction to \(31.4\%\) narrowed from - 4pts/2.4pts yoy in 4Q24/1Q25 and ahead of \(\sim 29\%\) guided mainly due to lower- than- expected sales & marketing expenses representing \(22.1\%\) of revenue (vs. \(23.5\%\) consensus and \(21.4\%\) in 1Q25). Net profit increased by a small magnitude \(+1\%\) yoy (vs. \(+3\%\) yoy in 1Q25) in absence of the mark- to- market gain from Makemytrip as in 2Q24 resulting in lower affiliate income of Rmb318mn (vs. Rmb1.1bn in 2Q24). Overall revenue contribution from domestic, outbound, Trip.com and Skyscanner retained quite steady qoq at \(64\%\) , \(15\%\) , \(14\%\) and \(7\%\) . Repeating the same profit breakdown exercise we did in prior quarter - we assume mild margin expansion for its domestic/outbound businesses given contribution from the more profitable advertising/VAS segments, we estimate Trip.com platform

BuyTrip.com Group (TCOM) Rating since Apr 19, 2021

incurred - Rmb0.2- 0.3bn EBIT loss with \(- 14\%\) margin in 2Q25 similar to the trend in prior quarter despite concern over increasing competition abroad, e.g., Booking.com, Agoda etc.

By segments, revenue from accommodation reservation business grew \(+21\%\) yoy (vs. \(+23\%\) in 1Q25) slightly ahead of guidance driven by \(+20\% / + 15\%\) yoy increase in outbound/domesticsooking volume (vs. \(+30\% /\) mid- teen % in 1Q25) and narrower ADR decline at low- single digit (LSD) % vs. mid- single digit % (MSD) yoy in prior quarter, consistent with H World/Atour's earlier comments and outperforming the industry - \(6\%\) per STR. This tracked behind flatfish ADR for Tongcheng - the latter more exposed to the low- end segment where supply grows more slowly. As a proxy of industry supply, the number of hotels listing on TCOM's platform increased by mid to high- single digit % ytd after stabilization in 2H24. Booking volume growth on Trip.com remained strong \(+ - 70\%\) yoy. Transportation ticketing business posted \(+11\%\) yoy revenue growth (vs. \(+8\%\) in 1Q25) with a pickup in sale volume for domestic routes up LSD yoy vs. flatfish in 1Q25 partly offset by continued normalization in outbound travel (+15% vs. \(- 20\%\) yoy in 1Q25). Take rate improved slightly as more people use its value- added services on both air flights and railways. The group continues to offer competitive air ticket prices to cross- sell its hotel booking services for overseas users on its Trip.com platform (+60% volume). Packaged tour revenue growth was relatively slow (+5% yoy vs. \(+7\%\) in 1Q25) dragged by weaker demand for standardized tours in China (- MSD % yoy) post the pandemic even though takeup for overseas tours remains healthy, i.e., \(+20\%\) yoy for outbound Chinese and \(+40\%\) for international users. Corporate travel revenue grew \(+9\%\) yoy (vs. \(+11\%\) in 1Q25) with \(- 80\%\) contribution from domestic trips arranged for MNC/SMEs. Other revenue increased by \(+31\%\) (vs. \(+33\%\) yoy in 1Q25) boosted by strong advertising revenue growth mainly by international hotel groups/tourism boards, as well as financing charges/fintech fees with more young travelers using their "buy now, pay later" services.

Even though China's travel demand has largely normalized after 2- 3 years post reopening, management still sounded optimistic about its business outlook on the group conference and follow- up calls we had with them earlier, highlighting healthy domestic hotel (+10- 15%), outbound travel (15- 20%) and inbound travel (+100%) volume growth in 3Qtd, while airfares have been more choppy, i.e., domestic - 3% yoy as of late vs. \(+5\%\) in May, international - 20% yoy vs. \(+7\%\) in May. When asked about competition (i.e., JD, Fliggy, Umetrip/航旅纵横), management reiterate their competitive niches rest on broad product coverage, comprehensive mobile apps/interactive platforms and quality customer services - these are hard to replicate. They have no intention to compete on prices as others do. The group has continued to make steady progress on the several strategic initiatives and focus they articulated in past results briefing: (1) Inbound travels for which its booking volume has doubled yoy, outpacing \(+30\%\) yoy for the industry including \(71\%\) from visa- free regions. This reflects TCOM's dominant position as a trust and preferred choice for foreigners visiting China given its extensive product coverage and strong local relationship. It recently launched the country's first inbound travel service center at Beijing International Airport offering multilingual assistants for instant booking and other travel- related services, e.g., forex, transport, global shopping, along with its

complimentary half- day tour in the city; (2) Silver generation served by its Old Friend Club which saw its GMV increased by \(100 + \%\) since end- FY24, facilitated by a variety of themed travel products (e.g., photography tours, live music, wellness retreats) and its recently- opened first offline Old Fan Club store in Shanghai - they expect to roll out more similar offline points in major travel hubs ahead; (3) Al and innovation to provide its users with end- to- end solutions and more accurate recommendations in coming up with personalized itineraries by integrating different transportation, accommodation and other travel options, verification of real- time data and a rich content ecosystem to avoid common issues such as long wait, transfer time.

For 3Q25 as a whole, the company guides steady \(+12 - 17\%\) yoy revenue growth to Rmb17.8- 18.6bn (vs. \(+16\%\) yoy in 1Q/2Q25) including accommodation reservation (+14- 19% yoy to Rmb7.8- 8.1bn on 10- 15% domestic and \(- 20\%\) outbound volume growth along with narrower LSD% ADR decline), transportation ticketing (+7- 12% to Rmb6- 6.3bn on LSD domestic, mid- teen % outbound and 50% yoy Trip.com volume growth), packaged tours (+7- 12% yoy to Rmb1.6- 1.7bn) and corporate travels (+7- 12% yoy to Rmb0.7- 0.8bn). Based on stable gross margin of 81% inline with 81% in 2Q25, \(+10\%\) yoy increase in product & development expenses and \(+23\%\) in sales & market expenses or \(22.5\%\) of revenue (vs. \(21\%\) in 3Q24), we model \(+10\%\) yoy EBIT growth to Rmb6bn with \(33\%\) margin (vs. \(34.4\%\) in 3Q24). For the full year, management maintain their revenue growth guidance largely unchanged at \(- 15\%\) yoy taking into account further slowdown in outbound travel revenue (low- teen % yoy in 2H25 vs. \(+19\% / + 15\%\) yoy in 1Q/2Q25) but relatively resilient domestic revenue growth (+9% in 2H25 vs. \(+10\% / + 11\%\) in 1Q/2Q25). They sound more optimistic about its margin trend after beating for two consecutive quarters (i.e., - 2.4pts/- 1.7pts yoy in 1Q/2Q25 vs. - 4pts guided). Overall, we model \(+15\%\) revenue and \(+10\%\) EBIT growth in FY25E, implying \(29\%\) EBIT margin (vs. its prior guidance of \(27.5 - 28\%\) ). As a reality check, this would imply a modest 1pts yoy margin expansion for its domestic/outbound business and - 5pts yoy wider margin loss for Trip.com platform taking into unfavorable revenue mix shift with the latter growth outpacing the former - Exhibit 4 - Exhibit 5 lays out how its blended EBIT and yoy growth would look like based on different revenue/EBIT loss assumptions for Trip.com.

As far as shareholder returns are concerned, the group has fully utilized the US \(400mn quota under the share repurchase program approved in Feb this year to acquire 7mn ADS or \(- 1\%\) of its o/s shares in the opening market at an average of US \(57 / share. It still has US\) 200mn unutilized quota under its 2014 repurchase plan allowing themselves to buy back more shares in the NASDAQ. Additionally, the company announced today that the board has authorized a new share repurchase program up to US\) 5bn (representing 11% of its market cap) on either NASDAQ and HK Stock Exchanges with no expiry date. As a recap, TCOM recently completed its divestment of partial interest in MakeMyTrip in July and received less than US \(3bn cash proceeds, net of associated fees. Its equity interest in MakeMyTrip is reduced to 16.9% after this transaction. The US\) 5bn new repurchase program would include another \(\sim US\) 2bn add- on well funded by the group's US\) 13bn (or Rmb94bn) cash balance at end- 2Q25. At the call, management have not provided any guidance or details about the pace of its

share repurchase under this newly announced program, but mentioned that they will buy back at least sufficient shares to neutralize the \(1.5 - 2\%\) dilutive impact from issuance of stock options each year. The group will continue to assess its financial condition and may announce another capital return program later this or early next year likely skewed more toward dividend distribution. Its US \(600mn capital return program announced earlier this year included both dividend distribution (US\) 200mn) and share repurchase (US\)400mn) together implying \(\sim 30\%\) FCF payout.

Factoring in slightly higher revenue and margin assumptions as laid out in Exhibit 6, we revise our FY25- 27E non- GAAP EPS for TCOM by \(0 - 2\%\) . Rolling over to FY26, we raise our 12- month SOTP- based target price to US \(87/HK\) 679 (from US\)78/HK\)608). The stock reacted positively \(+8\%\) today possibly attributed to its announcement of the US \(5bn share repurchase program, although the pace of its buyback is uncertain and still subject to market condition as noted above. To the extent that investors worried about potential downward revisions to its 3Q/FY25 guidance given the weaker travel data in July, the group's unchanged FY25 revenue guidance and more positive tone toward 2H25 margin trend could bode better for stock sentiment in the near term. Indeed, we have noticed some pickup in hotel RevPar and travel data in Aug mtd. Meanwhile, management continues to execute on its overseas expansion and various growth initiatives highlighted earlier. Its valuation does not look demanding looking out in FY26 when it is trading at 15x P/E and \(5.6\%\) FCF yield. Maintain Buy.

- TCOM's accommodation revenue in 2Q25 grew \(+21\%\) yoy (vs. \(+23\%\) in 1Q25), slightly above prior guidance of \(15 - 20\%\) . By regions, domestic hotel revenue maintained healthy growth at \(14 - 15\%\) (vs. \(+15\%\) in 1Q25) with narrowing ADR decline from mid-to-high single-digit % yoy to low-single-digit % outperforming industry (per STR - Exhibit 7) while booking volume growth moderated to mid-teens % (vs. \(15 - 20\%\) in 1Q25) on higher base. Blended take rate remained stable at \(-8.5\%\) with slight improvement for lower-segment hotels, inline with Tongcheng (Aug 19). Outbound hotel revenue growth moderated to \(-20\%\) yoy (vs. \(+30\%\) in 1Q25) driven by normalizing volume growth to high-teens % level while room rates remained flattish. For pure international business, Trip.com's hotel revenue maintained strong growth of \(+70\%\) yoy, similar to that in 1Q25.

- Overall transportation ticketing revenue growth re-accelerated to \(+11\%\) yoy (vs. \(+8\%\) in 1Q25), inline with guidance of \(+7 - 12\%\) mainly helped by reversing trend of domestic air ticketing business at \(+\) low-single-digit % growth (vs. decline in 1Q25) with improvement in booking volume (+low-single-digit % growth in 2Q25) as well as narrowing airfare decline (see our air travel tracker). Outbound air ticketing revenue grew by \(+5\%\) yoy (vs. \(+10\%\) in 1Q25) driven by normalizing volume growth and airfare decline. For context, outbound flight capacity recovery remained at \(-85\%\) of pre-COVID level as of end-2Q25, similar to 1Q25. For its Trip.com

platform, air ticketing volume maintained robust growth of \(50+\) %yoy supported by continued efforts on marketing investment as well as increasing demand for inbound travel to China. Separately for Skyscanner, revenue growth slightly improved to high- single- digit % growth in 2Q25 (from mid- single- digit % in 1Q25).

Despite the soft business travel demand due to macro uncertainties in 2Q25, TCOM's corporate travel business revenue achieved \(+9\%\) yoy growth (vs. \(+12\%\) in 1Q25) supported by growing corporate customer base amid improving penetration of business travel management. Separately, other revenue also maintained strong growth at \(+31\%\) yoy in 2Q25 (vs. \(+33\%\) in 1Q25) driven by growth from 1) advertising business with expanding collaboration with global travel partners (i.e., hotel group, local tourism bureau, etc.), 2) fintech business particularly from younger customers who are more inclined to adopt the 'Buy Now, Pay Later' services.

Looking ahead, management remained cautiously optimistic about its business outlook in FY25 and maintained revenue guidance unchanged at \(+14 - 15\%\) yoy growth considering the high base for both outbound travel and Trip.com businesses in 2H24. For 3Q25, they expect group revenue growth at \(+12 - 17\%\) yoy (vs. \(+16\%\) in 1Q/2Q25) with outbound revenue further moderating to low- teens %. According to our tracker gathered from CAAC and FlightMaster (Exhibit 10), outbound passenger traffic (carried by Chinese airlines) grew at \(+13\% / + 12\%\) in July/Aug- 25 vs. \(+21\%\) in 2Q25. Domestic revenue is expected to maintain stable growth at \(\sim 10\%\) yoy mainly driven by hotel booking growth at low- teens % while ADR likely to remain at low- single- digit % decline. For Trip.com platform, they target to maintain revenue growth at over \(+50\%\) yoy in 3Q25 but also noted a slowdown to \(\sim 40\%\) in 4Q25 given the high base last year. According to our monthly tracker form SensorTower, Trip.com's MAU in key Asia market maintained strong growth in Aug- 25 across key Asian markets (Exhibit 14 - Exhibit 16) led by Indonesia ( \(120+\) yoy), Japan \((+68\%)\) , and Thailand \((+66\%)\) .

TCOM's 2Q25 EBIT margin came higher than company's prior guidance \((- 29\%)\) at \(31.4\%\) mainly helped by higher marketing efficiency with sales and marketing ratio maintained at \(22\%\) of revenue (vs. guided \(24\%\) ). Product development and G&A expenses which are mostly personnel- related remained largely stable qoq. Looking into 2H25, management guided \(22 - 23\%\) sales and marketing ratio in 3Q25 and a sequentially higher ratio in 4Q25 given the overseas travel peak season. Net- net, we estimate EBIT margin at \(33\%\) in 3Q25E, - 1.4pts yoy vs. - 2.4pts/- 1.7pts in 1Q/2Q25.

As mentioned in our several previous reports (H World, Atour, Tongcheng, Air Travel Tracker), domestic travel demand especially long- haul travel during the past summer holiday performed softer than our expectation with air travel traffic growing at \(+2\%\)

yoy, resulting in weaker airfare at high- single- digit % decline (incl. fuel- surcharges). That said, industry hotel ADR decline narrowed to \(\sim - 2\%\) (vs. \(- 6\%\) in 2Q25) on easier basis while hotel supply growth is gradually normalizing given a slowdown in new signings, per hotel operators. Outbound air flight capacity remained at \(\sim 85\%\) recovery rate and air travel traffic growth (carried by Chinese airlines) moderated to \(+13\% / + 12\%\) in Jul/Aug recovering to \(\sim 105\%\) of pre- COVID levels.

In terms of shareholder return, the group has completed its capital return program announced in Feb- 25, having fully utilized the US\$400mn share buyback quota to repurchase total 7mn (1.1% of total) ADS by Aug 27, 2025. Meanwhile, they announced a new buyback program of up to USD5bn partly funded by \~USD3bn proceeds from partial disposal of investment in MakeMyTrip to repurchase its HK listed shares and/or ADSs in the next few years. While the concrete timeline is not decided, management noted the annual buyback should at least offset the share dilution from share- based- compensation (i.e., \(1.5 - 2\%\) p.a. historically).
Cash balance including cash and cash equivalents, restricted cash, short- term investment, held to maturity time deposit and financial products was Rmb94.1bn (US\$13.1bn) as of Jun- 25, \(+7\%\) qoq.
The company has net cash/net working capital of Rmb54.4bn/29.1bn (or US\$7.6bn/4.0bn) as of Jun- 25.

Trip.com is China's dominant domestic online travel agency providing full travel booking services across hotels, airlines, ground transportation, tourist attractions and package tours both domestically internationally. We are Buy rated on Trip.com (both ADR and H share) given 1) continuing market share gains with increasing penetration in lower- tier cities and new content strategy; 2) upside from overseas businesses; and 3) EBITDA upside from potentially higher hotel RevPar. Trading at below mid- cycle P/E, we see the current valuation as undemanding.

We, Simon Cheung, CFA, Leah Pan, Alpha Wang and Zhaohong Chen, hereby certify that all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect our personal views about the subject company or companies and its or their securities. We also certify that no part of our compensation was, is or will be, directly or indirectly, related to the specific recommendations or views expressed in this report.
Unless otherwise stated, the individuals listed on the cover page of this report are analysts in Goldman Sachs' Global Investment Research division.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Quantum is Goldman Sachs' proprietary database providing access to detailed financial statement histories, forecasts and ratios. It can be used for in- depth analysis of a single company, or to make comparisons between companies in different sectors and markets.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for Sells on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Not Rated (NR). The investment rating, target price and earnings estimates (where relevant) are removed pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when Goldman Sachs is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or in a strategic transaction involving this company, when there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints due to Goldman Sachs' involvement in a transaction, and in certain other circumstances. Early- Stage Biotech (ES). An investment rating and a target price are not assigned pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when this company neither has a drug, treatment or medical device that has passed a Phase II clinical trial nor a license to distribute a post- Phase II drug, treatment or medical device.
